title: Eric G. Blackman
text:
Eric Glen Blackman (born September 21, 1968 in <a href="Rochester%2C%20New%20York">Rochester, New York</a>) is an American astrophysicist and professor.
Education and career.
Blackman graduated from the <a href="Harley%20School">Harley School</a>, and then 
obtained undergraduate degrees in physics and mathematics from the <a href="Massachusetts%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Massachusetts Institute of Technology</a>. He worked at the <a href="General%20Electric%20Research%20Laboratory">General Electric Research Laboratory</a> during undergraduate summers. He subsequently completed a Master of Advanced Study in mathematics (applied math/theoretical physics, Tripos Part III) at <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a>, residing at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>, followed by a Phd at <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> working in theoretical astrophysics with George B. Field. He was a postdoctoral fellow at the 
<a href="Institute%20of%20Astronomy%2C%20Cambridge">Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge</a> of <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a> and in physics at <a href="Caltech">Caltech</a>
before joining the Department of Physics and Astronomy faculty at the <a href="University%20of%20Rochester">University of Rochester</a>
Blackman has made diverse contributions to theoretical astrophysics through 250+ research publications on topics that include stellar and planetary astrophysics, molecular clouds, planetary nebulae, accretion, jets, particle acceleration, turbulence, laboratory astrophysics, and relativistic astrophysics—including <a href="gamma-ray%20bursts">gamma-ray bursts</a> and <a href="active%20galactic%20nuclei">active galactic nuclei</a>. He is particularly known for work in <a href="plasma%20astrophysics">plasma astrophysics</a> involving magnetic fields, and principles of astrophysical <a href="dynamo">dynamo</a> theory—the latter being a theory of magnetic field origin in astrophysical objects such as <a href="galaxies">galaxies</a>, <a href="stars">stars</a>, <a href="accretion%20disks">accretion disks</a> and <a href="planets">planets</a>. Blackman has also worked on the mechanics and biomechanics of helmet protection against closed <a href="traumatic%20brain%20injury">traumatic brain injury</a>, identifying protection deficiencies in standard helmets for both head impacts and blast exposure.
